definitions: small fleet of ships or boats operating together as a unit
examples: The fishing flotilla returned to port before sunset
A naval flotilla patrolled the contested waters for months

definitions: debris or goods floating on water after a shipwreck
examples: Flotsam washed ashore after the storm passed
They searched the flotsam for survivors of the accident

definitions: bottom-dwelling marine fish with both eyes on one side
act of struggling clumsily or showing confusion
examples: The flounder camouflaged itself against the sandy bottom
Fresh flounder makes an excellent dinner when properly prepared
His flounder in the debate cost him crucial support
The company's flounder lasted months before bankruptcy

definitions: fine powder made by grinding wheat or other grains
examples: She sifted the flour before making the cake
Whole wheat flour provides more nutrients than white flour

definitions: ornamental stroke or curve in handwriting or decoration
period of thriving development or successful achievement
examples: The calligrapher added a flourish to each capital letter
His signature ended with an elaborate flourish
The artistic flourish of the Renaissance transformed European culture
Their business experienced a flourish after the merger

definitions: steady continuous stream of liquid or gas
smooth continuous movement or supply of something
examples: The flow of water increased after heavy rains
Blood flow to the brain requires careful monitoring
The flow of information improved with new technology
Traffic flow through downtown remains problematic during rush hour

definitions: colorful part of a plant containing reproductive organs
period when something is at its best or most successful
examples: The flower attracted bees with its bright petals
She arranged flowers in a crystal vase
The flower of youth passes quickly for athletes
Their civilization reached its flower during the classical period

definitions: process of producing flowers or being in bloom
period of greatest development or achievement
examples: The flowering of cherry trees attracts many tourists
Early flowering can be damaged by late frosts
The flowering of democracy took centuries to achieve
Her artistic flowering began after moving to Paris

definitions: quality of moving smoothly and continuously like liquid
examples: The dancer's flowing movements captivated the audience
Her flowing hair caught everyone's attention

definitions: contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses
examples: The flu outbreak closed several schools last winter
She recovered from the flu after a week of rest

definitions: irregular rising and falling in number, amount, or level
examples: Market fluctuations made investors nervous about their portfolios
Temperature fluctuations can damage sensitive equipment

definitions: duct or pipe for conveying smoke and gases from a fireplace
examples: The flue needed cleaning before winter heating season
Smoke backed up when the flue became blocked

definitions: ability to speak or write a language easily and accurately
examples: Her fluency in three languages impressed the hiring committee
Reading extensively helps develop fluency in writing

definitions: soft downy substance from fabric or feathers
entertainment or writing lacking serious content or substance
examples: She removed fluff from the dryer filter
The pillow leaked fluff through a small tear
The article was just fluff without any real analysis
Television fluff dominated the evening programming schedule

definitions: brass instrument similar to a cornet but with a wider conical bore
examples: The jazz musician played a soulful solo on the flugelhorn
His flugelhorn produced a warmer tone than the trumpet

definitions: substance that flows and takes the shape of its container
quality of being smooth, graceful, or readily changeable
examples: The mechanic checked all fluid levels in the engine
Intravenous fluids helped restore the patient's hydration
The fluid nature of the situation required flexible planning
Her fluid dance movements mesmerized the audience

definitions: physical property of flowing easily like a liquid
quality of being likely to change or adapt easily
examples: The fluidity of mercury makes it useful in thermometers
Oil's fluidity depends on its temperature
Gender fluidity challenges traditional binary classifications
The fluidity of modern careers requires continuous learning

definitions: unlikely chance occurrence or stroke of luck
either of the two lobes of a whale's tail
parasitic flatworm that infects liver or blood
examples: Winning the lottery was a complete fluke
Their victory seemed like a fluke until they won again
The whale's fluke slapped the water before diving
Researchers photographed the distinctive fluke pattern for identification
The sheep were treated for liver fluke infection
Blood flukes cause serious disease in tropical regions

definitions: artificial channel conveying water for industrial use or recreation
examples: The logging flume transported timber down the mountain
Children enjoyed riding the water flume at the park

definitions: emission of light by a substance that has absorbed radiation
examples: The fluorescence under ultraviolet light revealed hidden details
Marine creatures use fluorescence for communication and camouflage

definitions: quality of emitting light when exposed to radiation or electricity
examples: The fluorescent markers glowed under black light
They replaced incandescent bulbs with fluorescent lighting

definitions: addition of fluoride to water supplies to prevent tooth decay
examples: Community water fluoridation reduced childhood cavities significantly
The fluoridation debate continues in many municipalities

definitions: compound containing fluorine used in dental care and water treatment
examples: Fluoride toothpaste helps strengthen tooth enamel
The dentist applied fluoride treatment to prevent cavities

definitions: highly reactive pale yellow gas, the lightest halogen element
examples: Fluorine forms compounds with almost all other elements
Pure fluorine gas requires special handling due to its reactivity

definitions: selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor used to treat depression and anxiety
examples: The doctor prescribed fluoxetine for her depression symptoms
Fluoxetine takes several weeks to show therapeutic effects

definitions: light brief snowfall with wind
sudden short period of activity or excitement
examples: Snow flurries reduced visibility on the highway
Morning flurries gave way to afternoon sunshine
A flurry of activity preceded the president's arrival
The announcement triggered a flurry of phone calls

definitions: reddening of face or skin from emotion or heat
sudden flow of water for cleaning
poker hand with all cards of the same suit
examples: A flush spread across her cheeks when praised
The fever caused a noticeable flush on his face
The toilet flush mechanism needed repair
A powerful flush cleared the blocked drain
His flush beat her straight in the poker game
Drawing a royal flush happens once in 649,740 hands

definitions: woodwind instrument played by blowing across an opening
vertical groove as decoration on a column or surface
examples: She practiced flute for the orchestra audition
The silver flute produced a clear, bright tone
The architect specified flutes for the classical columns
Delicate flutes decorated the antique glassware

definitions: person who plays the flute professionally or skillfully
examples: The principal flutist led the woodwind section
A talented flutist joined the chamber music ensemble

definitions: quick light flapping movement especially of wings
state of nervous excitement or agitation
examples: The butterfly's flutter carried it between flowers
Curtains showed a gentle flutter in the breeze
She felt a flutter of anticipation before the interview
His arrival caused quite a flutter among the staff

definitions: continuous quick and light flapping or wavering movement
examples: The fluttering of leaves signaled approaching storm
Her fluttering eyelashes drew his attention immediately

definitions: continuous change or movement in state or condition
rate of flow of particles or energy through a surface
examples: Society remains in flux during technological revolution
The company's structure stayed in flux for months
Magnetic flux through the coil induced electric current
Scientists measured the flux of cosmic rays

definitions: small winged insect often found near food or waste
artificial fishing lure designed to resemble an insect
opening at the front of trousers fastened with zipper
examples: A fly buzzed around the kitchen window
The fly carried bacteria from garbage to food
He tied a dry fly for trout fishing
The salmon took the fly on the first cast
He quickly zipped his fly before the meeting
The fly on vintage trousers used buttons

definitions: small bird that catches insects in flight
examples: The flycatcher perched on a branch watching for prey
Spotted flycatchers migrate to Africa for winter

definitions: person who pilots or travels in aircraft
single-page advertisement or announcement for distribution
speculative or risky business venture or investment
examples: Frequent flyers earn rewards through airline programs
The military flyer completed her hundredth mission
Students distributed flyers about the campus event
Pizza flyers filled the apartment building's mailboxes
Taking a flyer on that startup proved profitable
His flyer in commodities trading lost everything

definitions: act of traveling through air in an aircraft
examples: Flying remains the fastest way to travel internationally
Her fear of flying limited vacation options

definitions: bridge carrying one road or railway over another
ceremonial flight of aircraft over a specific location
examples: The new flyover reduced traffic congestion downtown
Pedestrians used the flyover to cross safely
The military flyover thrilled spectators at the game
A flyover of vintage planes commemorated the anniversary

definitions: established air route used by migrating birds
examples: The Atlantic flyway extends from Arctic to Caribbean
Conservation efforts protect critical flyway habitats

definitions: lightest standard weight division in professional boxing
examples: The flyweight champion defended his title successfully
Flyweight boxers weigh no more than 112 pounds

definitions: heavy rotating wheel that stores kinetic energy in machinery
examples: The engine's flywheel smoothed power delivery between strokes
A damaged flywheel caused severe engine vibration

definitions: horse less than one year old of either sex
examples: The mare protected her foal from approaching strangers
Spring brings many foals to the breeding farm

definitions: mass of small bubbles formed in liquid
soft spongy synthetic material used for padding
examples: Sea foam collected along the beach after storms
The cappuccino had perfect foam on top
Memory foam mattresses conform to body shape
Foam insulation improved the home's energy efficiency

definitions: small ornament attached to a watch chain
small electronic device for keyless entry or security
examples: His antique pocket watch had an ivory fob
The decorative fob distinguished his watch chain
She used her key fob to unlock the car
The security fob granted access to the building

definitions: act of directing attention or effort to something specific
examples: Focusing on details improved her work quality
The team spent time focusing on customer needs

definitions: alternative spelling of focusing, directing attention to something
examples: Focussing on priorities helped meet the deadline
The report emphasized focussing on core competencies

definitions: dried food, especially hay or straw, for cattle and horses
raw material or information used to supply a continuous demand
examples: Farmers stored fodder for winter feeding
The drought reduced available fodder for livestock
Celebrity scandals became fodder for tabloid newspapers
His mistakes provided fodder for political opponents

definitions: person who feels enmity, hatred, or malice toward another
examples: Ancient foes signed a historic peace treaty
He considered ignorance his greatest foe

definitions: thick cloud of water droplets near ground level
state of mental confusion or lack of clarity
examples: Dense fog delayed morning flights at the airport
The fog lifted as the sun warmed the valley
She emerged from the fog of anesthesia slowly
His mind remained in a fog after the accident

definitions: loud horn sounded in fog to warn ships of danger
examples: The foghorn's deep blast echoed across the harbor
Ships relied on foghorns before modern navigation systems

definitions: very thin sheet of metal used for wrapping
person or thing that contrasts with and emphasizes another's qualities
light flexible sword used in fencing sport
examples: She wrapped leftovers in aluminum foil
Gold foil decorated the ancient manuscript
Watson served as a foil to Sherlock Holmes
The villain acted as a perfect foil to the hero
She won the tournament using an electric foil
Fencing foil requires different technique than épée
